title: R43557
content: The first section of the report outlines the FY2015 legislative branch appropriations process, including the initial request submission, hearings, markups, and passage of H.R. 4487. It also covers the enactment of continuing appropriations resolutions and the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015. The FY2015 legislative branch appropriations process included the enactment of the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015 (P.L. 113-235, Division H) on December 16, 2014. The report addresses prior year actions, funding, FY2015 budget requests, hearings, and funding issues for individual legislative branch agencies. The FY2015 U.S. Budget requested $4.471 billion in new budget authority for legislative branch activities. Dates of hearings for legislative branch subcommittees are listed in Table 2. The legislative branch appropriations process for FY2015 included hearings and markups of the bill, with a proposed housing stipend for Members living far from DC. The House Appropriations Committee reported the bill to the House, which took up consideration on May 1, 2014. The House of Representatives considered H.R. 4487 on May 1, 2014, with eight amendments, including funding for sexual harassment training and reducing funding for the Botanic Garden to FY2014 levels. The House of Representatives considered H.R. 4487 on May 1, 2014, with various amendments. Representative Gosar's amendment to reduce Botanic Garden funding to FY2014 levels and transfer funds to spending reduction passed. Representative Broun's amendment to reduce Capitol Visitor Center funding failed. Representative Duffy's amendment to defund the Open World Leadership Center Trust Fund failed. Representative Hall's amendment to prohibit printed copies of the Statement of Disbursements of the House passed. Representative Wenstrup's amendment to prohibit printed copies of the House daily calendar passed. The House passed H.R. 4487 with amendments, including one to prohibit funding for printed copies of the House daily calendar. Another amendment to reinstitute the Office of Technology Assessment failed. The Senate Appropriations Committee considered the bill but no further action was taken before the start of FY2015. Continuing appropriations resolutions provided funding for the legislative branch until the Consolidated and Further Continuing resolution was enacted. The FY2015 funding for the legislative branch was provided in the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015, with $4.3 billion allocated, an increase of 1.0% from FY2014. A funding gap in FY2014 led to a partial government shutdown for 16 days, which was resolved by a temporary continuing resolution and a consolidated appropriations bill. Following a temporary continuing resolution on January 15, 2014 (P.L. 113-73), a consolidated appropriations bill was enacted on January 17 (P.L. 113-76), providing $4.259 billion for the legislative branch for FY2014. FY2013 funding of approximately $4.061 billion was provided by P.L. 113-6, signed into law on March 26, 2013. The act funded legislative branch accounts at the FY2012 enacted level, with some exceptions, and less across-the-board rescissions required by Section 3004 of P.L. 113-6. Subsequent to the enactment of P.L. 113-6, OMB calculated additional rescissions of 0.032% of security. The Budget Control Act of 2011 and the American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012 amended the legislative branch budget. OMB calculated additional rescissions of 0.032% of security budget authority and 0.2% of nonsecurity budget authority after P.L. 113-6. Sequestration reductions implemented on March 1 reduced legislative branch accounts by 5.0%. Division G of the FY2012 Consolidated Appropriations Act provided $4.307 billion for the legislative branch, $236.9 million below the FY2011 level. The legislative branch budget decreased by $125.1 million in FY2011 compared to FY2010. Additional funding was provided for the Government Accountability Office in FY2009. The budget remains below the FY2004 level in constant dollars. The Senate requested a 5.6% increase in funding for FY2015. The Senate requested a $907.2 million budget for FY2015, a 5.6% increase from FY2014. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $865.9 million, a 0.8% increase. The FY2015 act provided $864.3 million. The inquiries and investigations account received $134.0 million, with a 1.0% increase from FY2014. The Committee on Appropriations account remained at $14.94 million, the same as FY2014. The Senate requested $429.7 million for FY2015, with the Senate Appropriations Committee recommending and the FY2015 act providing $390.0 million, the same level as FY2014. The House requested $1.20 billion for FY2015, but the House-passed FY2015 level of $1.18 billion was continued in the FY2015 act. The House requested $1.20 billion for FY2015, an increase of 1.7%. The House-passed FY2015 level of $1.18 billion, which was continued in the FY2015 act, is equivalent to the FY2014 level. Funding for House committees is contained in the appropriation heading "committee employees," with two subheadings for personnel and nonpersonnel expenses. The House requested $126.3 million for personnel and nonpersonnel expenses of House committees, while the Committee on Appropriations requested $23.7 million. Both amounts saw a 2.0% increase, with the FY2015 act maintaining the same levels as FY2014. The House requested $23.7 million for the Committee on Appropriations, a 2.0% increase from FY2014. The Members' Representational Allowance (MRA) was requested at $565.4 million, also a 2.0% increase. The U.S. Capitol Police (USCP) requested $355.7 million for FY2015, a 5.1% increase from FY2014. The House-passed bill would have provided $348.0 million for the USCP. The U.S. Capitol Police (USCP) received $355.7 million for FY2015, a 5.1% increase from FY2014. The House-passed bill proposed $348.0 million, while the Senate-reported version suggested $344.0 million. The appropriations for the police are divided into salaries and general expenses accounts, covering employee salaries, benefits, equipment, training, and other operational costs. The U.S. Capitol Police requested funding for various expenses including salaries, equipment, training programs, and general expenses. The requested amount for salaries was $291.4 million, an increase of 4.4% from the previous year. For general expenses, they requested $64.3 million, an 8.1% increase. The House-passed bill would have provided $286.5 million for salaries and $61.5 million for general expenses. The House-passed bill provided $61.5 million for Capitol Police buildings and grounds, while the Senate Appropriations Committee recommended an increase from the FY2014 enacted level. USCP requested $25.6 million, with the House bill proposing $19.5 million and the Senate bill recommending $20.7 million. Discussions on Capitol Police training, radio modernization, recent incidents, overtime use, and discrimination complaints were held in a House subcommittee meeting. The Office of Compliance, an independent agency, administers the Congressional Accountability Act. They requested $4.02 million for FY2015, with the House Appropriations Committee recommending $3.96 million. Discussions on USCP incidents, increased access, and funding levels were held in a Senate subcommittee hearing on March 25, 2014. The House Appropriations Committee recommended $3.96 million for FY2015, with the Senate-reported bill also providing the same amount. The Senate-reported version of H.R. 4487 included language authorizing electronic notifications for covered employees by the Office of Compliance. CBO provides objective economic and budgetary analysis to Congress. The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) provides economic and budgetary analysis to Congress. CBO requested $46.1 million for FY2015, with the House-passed bill providing $45.7 million and the Senate-reported bill providing $46.1 million. Discussions at hearings included CBO projections and methodologies. CBO requested two administrative provisions for FY2015 funds. The Architect of the Capitol is responsible for maintaining and operating the U.S. Capitol Complex, including various buildings and grounds. Operations are funded through 10 accounts, with provisions for FY2015 funds for compensation of employees in specialty occupations with non-immigrant visas and unobligated balances available through FY2016. Neither the House-passed nor Senate-reported versions of H.R. 4487 contained these provisions. The Architect of the Capitol requested $676.6 million for FY2015, an increase of 12.4% from FY2014. The House-passed bill would have provided $484.9 million, including amendments to reduce funding for the Botanic Garden and offset from the general fund. The House-passed bill for FY2015 would have provided $484.9 million, with amendments to reduce funding for the Botanic Garden and offset training costs. The Senate-reported bill proposed $600.0 million, while the FY2015 enacted level was $600.2 million (-0.3%). Administrative provisions in the House-passed and Senate-reported versions of H.R. 4487 focused on scrims and educational outreach efforts. The FY2015 bill contained provisions related to educational outreach efforts of the U.S. Botanic Garden and funding discussions for Capitol Dome rehabilitation and Cannon House Office Building renovation. The Library of Congress serves as both Congress's library and the national library, with a collection of over 158 million items. The Library of Congress provides a wide range of services to the nation, including maintaining a collection of over 158 million items, administering U.S. copyright laws, and providing reading material to the blind and physically handicapped. It also offers legal research and law-related services to Congress through the Law Library of Congress and conducts public policy research, analysis, and legislative assistance for Members and committees through the Congressional Research Service. The Library requested $593.1 million for FY2015, a 2.4% increase from the previous year. The Library of Congress requested $593.1 million for FY2015, an increase of 2.4% from the previous year. The House-passed bill would have provided $594.95 million, the Senate-reported bill would have provided $587.4 million, and the FY2015 act provided $590.9 million. Salaries and expenses saw an increase to $413.0 million, and the Copyright Office received $18.2 million in the FY2014 act. The FY2014 act provided $409.8 million, FY2015 act provided $413.0 million. Copyright Office received $18.2 million in FY2014. Library requested $19.5 million for Copyright Office in FY2015. House-passed bill would have provided $20.7 million, Senate-reported level would have provided $19.56 million. Congressional Research Service received $105.4 million in FY2014. FY2015 act provided $106.9 million. Books for the Blind and Physically Handicapped received $49.8 million in FY2014. Library requested $50.7 million. The FY2014 act provided $49.8 million for Books for the Blind and Physically Handicapped. The Library requested $50.7 million for FY2015. The FY2015 act provided the Senate-reported level. The Architect's budget included funds for Library buildings and grounds, with $62.8 million requested for FY2015. The House-passed bill would have provided $41.7 million, and the Senate-reported bill would have provided $47.6 million. The FY2015 act provided $42.2 million. The Library also requested authority to obligate funds for reimbursable and revolving fund activities. The Library requested authority to obligate funds for reimbursable and revolving fund activities, which was included in the House-passed and Senate-reported bills and the FY2015 act. Hearings in 2014 discussed issues in the Copyright Office, management and planning within the Library, plans for the Twitter archive, and book preservation. GPO requested $128.9 million for FY2015, with the House-passed bill providing $122.6 million and the Senate-reported bill providing $122.1 million. The FY2015 act provided $119.99 million. The Senate-reported bill proposed a $122.1 million budget for the Government Publishing Office, an increase of 2.4% from the previous year. The budget is divided into three accounts, with changes in account names from the FY2015 act. The House-passed bill and Senate-reported bill had differing amounts allocated for congressional publishing and Public Information Programs of the Superintendent of Documents. The Government Publishing Office requested $32.2 million for Public Information Programs in FY2015, with the enacted bill providing $31.5 million. The Business Operations Revolving fund received $8.8 million in FY2015, an increase of $693,000 from the previous year. The Senate-reported bill included a provision to rename the Government Printing Office as the Government Publishing Office. The Government Printing Office was renamed the Government Publishing Office in the FY2015 act. The House subcommittee discussed various topics including agency activities during funding lapse, printing costs, and the Federal Digital System. GAO requested $525.1 million for FY2015 for studies on government programs and expenditures. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) requested $525.1 million for FY2015 for studies on federal government programs and expenditures. This represented a 3.9% increase from the previous year. The FY2015 act provided $522.0 million, with three administrative provisions requested by GAO. These provisions included amending reviews and reports required by the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, authorizing personnel detail from other branches or agencies, and establishing a fee-based Center for Audit Excellence. The House and Senate discussed establishing the Center for Audit Excellence on a fee-based basis. The Open World Leadership Center supports democratic changes by inviting leaders from other countries to observe democracy in the United States. The Open World Leadership Center was established in 2000 at the Library of Congress to support the relationship between Russia and the United States. It expanded in 2003 to include more countries and requested $8.0 million for FY2015, an increase of 33.3% from the previous year. The Open World Leadership Center requested $8.0 million for FY2015, a 33.3% increase from the previous year. The House-passed bill proposed $3.42 million (-43.0%), while the Senate-reported bill suggested $5.7 million, a decrease of $300,000 (-5.0%) from FY2014. The center was created in 1988 to promote public service through training programs and requested $430,000 for FY2015, the same as in FY2014. The Stennis Center received $430,000 in FY2013, with the Senate-reported bill supporting this amount. However, the House-passed bill did not provide funding due to a lack of detailed budget justification. The center was created in 1988 with an initial appropriation of $7.5 million. The FY2012 conference report followed language in H.Rept. 112-148, stating that the John C. Stennis Center for Public Service Training and Development was created in 1988 with an initial appropriation of $7.5 million. The Center currently has $15 million invested with the Treasury, generating $300,000 annually at a 2 percent return. Due to reduced funding within the Legislative Branch, the Committee provided zero funding for the Center and directed that any future budget requests be accompanied by a detailed budget justification. The John C. Stennis Center for Public Service Training and Development received $430,000 in funding in FY2011, with recurring provisions in H.R. 4487 and P.L. 113-235. The budget request must be accompanied by a detailed justification in the future. The House-passed and Senate-reported versions of H.R. 4487 included provisions authorizing costs for the Legislative Branch Financial Managers Council, landscape maintenance by the AOC, limiting transfers, and prohibiting restrictions on guided staff tours of the Capitol. Division N of the FY2015 act enacted a freeze on pay for Members of Congress, although salaries for Members of Congress are not funded or increased in any appropriations bill. Provisions to prohibit automatic pay adjustments have been discussed in previous years and could be included in future bills or introduced separately. The Senate-reported bill included restrictions on bonus awards to contractors for projects behind schedule or over budget. P.L. 113-235 prohibits funds for painting portraits of federal government officials. Funding levels for the legislative branch are detailed in Tables 4-8. The funding levels for the legislative branch, Senate, House of Representatives, Capitol Police, and Architect of the Capitol are detailed in Tables 4-8. An Appendix lists bills, reports, public law numbers, and enactment dates since FY1998. Selected websites provide information on legislative branch appropriations requests and the appropriations process.
